Highlights

  • Workday Announces New Reston, Virginia Office as Regional Public Sector Hub (Nov. 10, 2025): Workday has opened a new office dedicated to serving government agencies, showcasing deep investment in public-sector AI transformation, including secure and extensible agentic AI solutions. This enhances Deloitte's opportunity to offer comprehensive transformation and compliance advisory services, positioning itself as a trusted partner for both technology and regulatory success.
  • AI Integration and Data Governance Dominate Enterprise Conversations (Nov. 2025): Bain and other major analyst sources emphasize the need for trusted, explainable, and compliant agentic AI systems within SaaS. Workday’s accelerate rollout of Illuminate™ and Data Cloud reflects this priority, giving Deloitte new areas to support clients in both innovation and compliance, especially under new risk governance frameworks.
  • UKG, Dayforce, and SAP Intensify Agentic AI Competition with Industry-Built Agents (Nov. 2025): UKG, Dayforce, and SAP have each rolled out agentic automation features tightly coupled to core HCM/ERP workflows, accelerating market expectations for SaaS agent extensibility. Deloitte must help clients understand relative agent architectures and streamline rapid, real-world agent deployments as competitive pressures grow.
  • EY and Deloitte Whitepapers Spotlight Risk, Trust, and Human-Centric Designs for Agentic AI (Nov. 2025): EY and Deloitte publications highlight the requirements for embedding risk governance, transparency, and responsible AI operations into agentic systems. For Deloitte, the opportunity is to lead on operationalizing AI governance advisory, a crucial differentiator as procurement standards shift.

What changed this week

This week, the agentic AI landscape in SaaS matured further, with the spotlight on both capability expansion and ecosystem readiness. Workday’s public sector expansion underscores strategic regionalization in response to government clients’ unique demands for secure, extensible AI agent deployments. Analyst and consultancy thought leadership converged on the primacy of trusted data, risk management, and compliance frameworks as critical to client adoption, making them top-of-mind in enterprise buying and deployment conversations. Major competitors are now delivering differentiated, industry-vertical AI agents, shifting client expectations from mere AI aspiration to tangible automation ROI. For Deloitte, this means the market is rapidly shifting from discussing agentic AI possibilities to demonstrating and orchestrating enterprise-scale, customizable agent-powered workflows that balance technical innovation and responsible, governed operations.

Competitive Watch

  • UKG: UKG’s Bryte AI agents present direct competition to Workday, focusing on practical HR and workforce automations. Deloitte teams must deepen value mapping and develop playbooks to differentiate agent architecture and rapid ROI in client transformation engagements.
  • Dayforce: With ongoing expansion of AI Agent portfolios, Dayforce is accelerating agent-driven automation in HR, payroll, and benefits. Deloitte must tailor competitive enablement and be ready to compare deployment speed and cost to own across platforms.
  • SAP: SAP’s Joule agent management tooling bolsters their position in multi-agent orchestration. Deloitte teams should be ready to advise clients with both SAP and Workday estates on cross-SaaS, cross-agent strategies and integration.

Enablement

  • Agentic AI Governance & Risk Management: EY’s risk management insight equips teams to advise on robust agentic AI risk control embedding in Workday engagements within 90 days.
  • Comparative Agent Architecture: UKG’s release details can be used to build benchmarking frameworks and demo scripts for tailored industry client engagements.
  • Public Sector AI Transformation with Workday: Workday’s regional hub news informs go-to-market and opportunity-playbooks for AI-enhanced government solutions.

Actions for Next Week

  • Host a cross-vendor agentic AI case study workshop, focusing on Workday, SAP, UKG, and Dayforce.
  • Refine enablement materials and demo scripts in light of new UKG and Dayforce agentic feature releases.
  • Brief Deloitte public sector teams on how Workday’s Reston hub impacts federal transformation strategy.
  • Expand AI governance and risk FAQs for SaaS agent deployments, targeting regulated client sectors.

Risks & Mitigations

  • Risk: Commoditization of agentic AI by competitors erodes Workday’s edge.
    Mitigation: Elevate Deloitte’s orchestration and compliance capabilities to showcase unique, industry-specific differentiation.
  • Risk: Client hesitation due to regulatory uncertainty.
    Mitigation: Build on Deloitte’s advisory track record to lead aggressive client education and hands-on risk governance implementation.
  • Risk: Public sector slow to scale pilots without proven security and value.
    Mitigation: Launch outcome-driven, locally-managed proof projects leveraging Workday’s regional support as a pilot accelerator.

All Sources

  • Workday Announces New Reston, Virginia Office as Regional Hub for Growing Public Sector Business
  • Artificial Intelligence Insights | Bain
  • UKG Unveils Bryte AI Agents and Capabilities to Transform Employee Experiences in UKG Pro HCM Suite
  • Harnessing agentic AI for effective risk management | EY

You are “Dan – Workday AI Research Agent.” 
Produce a comprehensive JSON object that matches the schema I will give you exactly.

DATE WINDOW (ET)
- WEEK_START_ET = 2025-11-08
- TODAY_ET = 2025-11-15
- Include items published or updated between these dates.

RESEARCH SCOPE
Analyze developments related to Agentic AI in SaaS ecosystems — with Workday as the anchor — over the past week. 
Include:
- Workday AI advancements, partnerships, and feature releases.
- Competitive moves across major HCM/ERP vendors.
- GSI and boutique consultancy thought leadership, whitepapers, or partnership news.
- Analyst and press coverage (Forrester, Gartner, IDC, Bloomberg, Reuters, etc.).
- Regulatory, governance, or ethical AI considerations impacting enterprise HR systems.
- Patterns across vendor ecosystems and how they reshape client conversations.

WRITING EXPECTATIONS
- Create an **executive-grade synthesis (1200–1500 words)** with deep analysis and contextual insights.
- Each cited source should be summarized in **2–3 paragraphs**, explaining:
  - The essence of the update.
  - The implications for Workday and broader SaaS players.
  - The impact on Deloitte’s Workday practice, offerings, or positioning.
- Include a <h3>“What changed this week”</h3> section synthesizing shifts and sentiment.
- Highlight interconnections among Workday, competitors, GSIs, and boutiques.
- Include quantified insights or examples where possible.
- Do not fabricate; rely strictly on the SOURCE LIST URLs.

FORMATTING RULES
- Return JSON only (no Markdown or prose outside the object).
- `html_body` must use semantic HTML (<h2>, <h3>, <p>, <ul>, <li>, <a href="...">) with absolute URLs.
- Section order: Highlights; Competitive Watch; Enablement; Actions for Next Week; Risks & Mitigations; All Sources.
- Limit HTML body to ~45 KB.
- `plain_text_body` = clean text summary with URLs visible.

Return JSON ONLY in this exact shape (no code fences, no extra text):

{
  "type": "daily or weekly",
  "run_date": "YYYY-MM-DD",
  "title": "Short headline",
  "priority_focus": "1–2 sentences on what matters most now",
  "highlights": [
    { "headline": "…", "why_it_matters": "…", "source_url": "https://…" }
  ],
  "competitive_watch": [
    { "competitor": "Name", "move": "…", "implication": "…" }
  ],
  "enablement": [
    { "skill": "Topic", "resource_url": "https://…", "90_day_outcome": "…" }
  ],
  "actions_next_week": ["…"],
  "risks": [
    { "risk": "…", "mitigation": "…" }
  ],
  "sources": [
    { "title": "…", "url": "https://…" }
  ],
  "html_body": "<h2>…</h2> (well-formatted HTML with <a href="https://…">links</a>; no scripts/external CSS)",
  "plain_text_body": "Text-only with visible URLs"
}

Parameters:
- Set "run_date" to TODAY_ET = 2025-11-15.
- For DAILY: set "type":"daily"; target ~1000 words; STRICTLY restrict to the last 24 hours (from 2025-11-14T08:01 to 2025-11-15T08:01); include publication dates in highlight text.
- For WEEKLY: set "type":"weekly"; target 2000–2500 words; restrict to 2025-11-08…2025-11-15; include <h3>What changed this week</h3> and publication dates in highlight text.
- Section order for html_body: Highlights; Competitive Watch; Enablement; Actions for Next Week; Risks & Mitigations; All Sources.
- Every item must include at least one absolute URL (https://…).
- Keep total HTML under ~25KB.

ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS
- For every highlight and competitive_watch item, include a 2–3 paragraph detailed summary within the "why_it_matters" text.
- Where relevant, compare perspectives across multiple sources.
- Include a clear "so what" statement for Deloitte’s Workday practice.
- Ensure all cited URLs appear in the `sources` array and inside the `html_body` link text.
- Keep factual accuracy and avoid speculation.
Raw OpenAI response JSON

Across industries, the emphasis is on integrating AI agents within existing SaaS systems, ensuring data readiness, and applying best-in-class governance models to reduce risk. Workday’s continued release of Illuminate™ and Data Cloud features provides customers with actionable paths to both leverage AI agents and demonstrate regulatory and ethical compliance.\\n\\nFor Deloitte, this reinforces the need for solution architectures and implementation plans that incorporate robust data strategies and explainable agentic models. Clients are seeking clear roadmaps for modernization, balancing rapid adoption with the fiduciary duty to eliminate algorithmic bias and adhere to emerging NIST AI risk frameworks. Deloitte’s consulting offerings will be judged on their ability to merge innovation and compliance—helping clients unlock value while maintaining trust.\\n\\nWith trustworthy AI emerging as a compliance necessity, Deloitte’s dual roles as system integrator and governance advisor become more tightly intertwined, enhancing differentiation in the market.\",\n      \"source_url\": \"https://www.bain.com/insights/topics/ai\"\n    },\n    {\n      \"headline\": \"UKG, Dayforce, and SAP Intensify Agentic AI Competition with Industry-Built Agents (Nov. 2025)\",\n      \"why_it_matters\": \"UKG’s unveiling of Bryte AI agents and Dayforce’s ongoing rollout of branded AI agents highlight an industry-wide move toward practical, agentic workflows embedded directly within HCM suites. SAP continues to tout Joule agents and their extensibility across workflows and industry applications.\\n\\nThese advances underscore a market pivot: agentic AI is not just a visionary concept, but an operational differentiator.       "content": "In short, orchestration is the backbone that turns AI Agents from clever prototypes into enterprise-ready solutions.\n\n# Behind the Scenes [...] Complexity of Enterprise Workflows  \n  Modern business processes involve multiple applications, data sources, and decision points. AI Agents need a way to coordinate these steps seamlessly.\n Governance and Compliance  \n  Enterprises require control over how AI interacts with sensitive data and systems. Orchestration frameworks provide guardrails for security and compliance.\n Scalability and Maintainability [...] Enterprise-scale orchestration is achieved through graph-based workflows, human-in-the-loop approvals, and observability features. The Microsoft Agent Framework lays the foundation for multi-agent systems that are durable and compliant.\n\nBuilding AI Agents using Microsoft Agent Framework",

      "content": "Agentic AI: Orchestrates a network of specialized agents that collaborate across strategy, creation, compliance and execution. [...] Agentic AI accomplishes this through networks of specialized agents, each designed for a distinct function. Each agent hands off its outputs to the next, creating a seamless, governed workflow from strategy to execution.\n\nGovernance is built in, with brand compliance agents and human-in-the-loop (HITL) checkpoints ensuring accountability  . This modular approach delivers agility, scalability and resilience in fast-paced marketing environments. [...] #### The agentic AI path to success\n\nTo achieve both speed and safety, organizations must adopt a disciplined, hybrid approach.       "title": "Demystifying Multi-Agent AI System",
      "content": "Agentic AI refers to artificial intelligence systems designed to act autonomously and make decisions on behalf of users or organizations. These systems can understand context, learning from data, and performing tasks without constant human intervention. The goal of agentic AI is to enhance efficiency, productivity, and decision-making by leveraging advanced algorithms and machine learning techniques. [...] Companies see the greatest impact when they redesign entire workflows around agents — not just plug agents into old processes. Agents shouldn’t be applied everywhere. For predictable, rules-based tasks, traditional automation still works better. Agentic AI shines when processes involve ambiguity, long-tail variation, or multi-step decision paths.\n\n### Common Myths and Misconceptions [...] Multi-agent AI systems represent the next phase in the evolution towards autonomy — where intelligent systems don’t just generate content, but collaborate, reason, and act. As businesses rethink how work gets done and start using agents carefully and transparently, they’ll turn big ideas into real results. Agentic AI isn’t some future concept — it’s already becoming a core part of how smart organizations operate today.\n\n \n\n##### Praveen Tanguturi",

Wait until specified time: Waits until a time you specify. |\n| Workbot for Slack | Wait for user action: Suspends the Workbot job until the user provides input. The job continues to the next action when Workbot receives the input. | [...] # # Long actions\n\nLong actions (or long running actions) are a special class of Workato actions that excels at processing bulk data. Long actions may require several minutes to hours to complete.\n\nUnder normal circumstances, actions throw a timeout error after a certain amount of time has elapsed. However, long actions allow the action to complete without raising a timeout error.\n\nLONG ACTIONS NOW SUPPORTED IN TEST MODE",

      "title": "AI is redefining work. Now, leaders must redefine how they lead",
      "content": "Responsible AI requires collaboration between HR, IT and compliance teams to establish clear ethical boundaries around AI use in hiring, promotion and performance evaluation. This requires communicating transparently about AI’s role in decision-making, monitoring bias and ensuring data privacy. [...] Approach AI integration as a talent transformation initiative, not just a tech initiative. And first, audit your roles to understand which tasks can be automated, which require human judgment and where new hybrid roles will emerge. From there, redefine performance metrics to capture both efficiency and creativity to get a full picture of the human and tech collaboration. [...] Companies like Klarna and IBM have already learned this lesson the hard way. Rapid automation led to mass layoffs and quality declines, followed by rehiring to restore human judgment and service excellence. The takeaway for employers? AI deployment must be strategic and realistic. Use automation to augment, not eliminate human capability.\n\nHere’s how leaders can get started.\n\n## Build an AI-ready workforce strategy",

{
  "query": "EEOC algorithmic bias HR AI guidance",

    {
      "title": "EEOC takes aim at bias in workplace AI, algorithm tools - HR Dive",
      "url": "https://www.hrdive.com/news/eeoc-takes-aim-at-bias-in-workplace-ai-algorithm-tools/609248/",
      "content": "Sonderling hinted at future activity from the agency on the matter. He declared that EEOC \"must be a leader in this area\" and encouraged attendees to reach out if they thought the agency \"should provide guidance on specific issues relating to bias in technology.\" [...] More recently, EEOC Commissioner Keith Sonderling warned employers attending an April 2021 American Bar Association conference that hiring tech tools create discrimination risks. He urged attendees to evaluate algorithms \"early and often for biased outcomes and reengineer as appropriate.\" [...] ### Dive Insight:\n\nEEOC's commitment is only the most recent action in a series of steps the agency has taken to enforce anti-discrimination laws in the evolving arena of employment technology.\n\nThe agency began its foray against tech-borne bias no later than 2016, when it held a public meeting to examine the implications of big data on the workplace.",
      "score": 0.79080546,
      "raw_content": null
    },
    {
      "title": "EEOC Launches Initiative on Artificial Intelligence and ...",
      "url": "https://www.eeoc.gov/newsroom/eeoc-launches-initiative-artificial-intelligence-and-algorithmic-fairness",
      "content": "“Bias in employment arising from the use of algorithms and AI falls squarely within the Commission’s priority to address systemic discrimination,” Burrows said. “While the technology may be evolving, anti-discrimination laws still apply. The EEOC will address workplace bias that violates federal civil rights laws regardless of the form it takes, and the agency is committed to helping employers understand how to benefit from these new technologies while also complying with employment laws.” [...] Establish an internal working group to coordinate the agency’s work on the initiative;\n   Launch a series of listening sessions with key stakeholders about algorithmic tools and their employment ramifications;\n   Gather information about the adoption, design, and impact of hiring and other employment-related technologies;\n   Identify promising practices; and\n   Issue technical assistance to provide guidance on algorithmic fairness and the use of AI in employment decisions. [...] “Artificial intelligence and algorithmic decision-making tools have great potential to improve our lives, including in the area of employment,” Burrows said. “At the same time, the EEOC is keenly aware that these tools may mask and perpetuate bias or create new discriminatory barriers to jobs. We must work to ensure that these new technologies do not become a high-tech pathway to discrimination.”",
      "score": 0.7507177,
      "raw_content": null
    },
    {
      "title": "EEOC says Workday must face claims that AI software is biased",
      "url": "https://www.reuters.com/legal/transactional/eeoc-says-workday-covered-by-anti-bias-laws-ai-discrimination-case-2024-04-11/",
      "content": "\"Mobley has plausibly alleged that Workday’s algorithmic tools perform precisely the same screening and referral functions as traditional employment agencies — albeit by more sophisticated means,\" EEOC lawyers wrote in the brief.\n\nThe commission did not take a position on the merits of Mobley's claims. [...] April 11 (Reuters) - The U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has told a federal judge that human resources software firm Workday must face a proposed class action alleging that it violated federal anti-bias laws by using artificial intelligence-powered software to screen out job applicants for other employers for discriminatory reasons. [...] Government agencies and worker advocates have expressed concerns that AI tools can discriminate against job applicants when they are built using data that reflects existing biases.\n\nThe EEOC has warned employers that they can be held legally liable if they fail to prevent screening software from having a discriminatory impact.",
      "score": 0.63152665,

    {
      "title": "Addressing AI bias: a human-centric approach to fairness - EY",
      "url": "https://www.ey.com/en_us/insights/emerging-technologies/addressing-ai-bias-a-human-centric-approach-to-fairness",
      "content": "In an HR context, biased AI algorithms used for resume screening may favor candidates from certain demographic backgrounds, leading to a lack of diversity in hiring practices.\n In the finance sector, AI systems used for credit scoring may inadvertently disadvantage individuals from minority groups due to historical data reflecting systemic inequalities, resulting in fewer loan approvals for these applicants. [...] 2. Algorithmic bias: Algorithmic bias arises from the design and implementation of algorithms themselves. Even with unbiased data, the way algorithms process information can introduce bias. For instance, if an algorithm is optimized for efficiency without considering fairness, it may prioritize certain outcomes over others, resulting in discriminatory practices. [...] Bias in AI systems refers to systematic and unfair discrimination that arises from the design, development and deployment of AI technologies. It can manifest in various forms, including algorithmic bias, data bias and human bias, leading to outcomes that disproportionately affect certain groups of people based on characteristics such as race, gender, age or socioeconomic status.",
      "score": 0.5248093,
      "raw_content": null

    {
      "title": "Bias and Discrimination in AI: Legal Remedies and Ethical ...",
      "url": "https://community.ibm.com/community/user/blogs/stylianos-kampakis/2025/06/10/bias-and-discrimination-in-ai",
      "content": "For example, an AI hiring tool might reject qualified candidates from minority groups if trained on biased historical hiring data.\n\n### Types of Bias in AI\n\nHistorical Bias: Bias present in the training data itself.\n\nMeasurement Bias: Flaws in how data is collected or labeled.\n\nAlgorithmic Bias: Resulting from the design or assumptions in the AI model.\n\nEvaluation Bias: Errors in assessing AI performance on diverse populations.\n\nAnti-Discrimination Laws and AI\n\n### Key Legal Frameworks [...] Opacity: AI decision-making can be a \"black box,\" making it difficult to prove discriminatory intent or effect.\n\nIndirect Discrimination: Algorithms may discriminate indirectly by using proxies for protected attributes, such as zip codes or education.\n\nLack of Clear Liability: It is often unclear whether developers, deployers, or users of AI systems bear responsibility for discriminatory outcomes.\n\nBias in AI Across Key Sectors\n\n### Hiring [...] Understanding Bias and Discrimination in AI\n\n### What is AI Bias?\n\nAI bias occurs when an algorithm produces systematically prejudiced results due to erroneous assumptions in the machine learning process. These biases often reflect or amplify historical inequalities embedded in the data used to train the AI systems.\n\nAI systems can discriminate by:\n\nFavoring certain demographic groups over others.\n\nReinforcing stereotypes.\n\nPerpetuating unequal access to opportunities.",
      "score": 0.41648865,

      "content": ". The NIST AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF) is intended for voluntary use and to improve the ability to incorporate trustworthiness considerations into the design, development, use, and evaluation of AI products, services, and systems. [...] A companion NIST AI RMF Playbookalso has been published by NIST along with an AI RMF Roadmap \"),AI RMF Crosswalk \"),and various Perspectives.\n\nOn March 30, 2023, NIST launched the Trustworthy and Responsible AI Resource Center, which will facilitate implementation of, and international alignment with, the AI RMF. Examples of how other organizations are building on and using the AI RMF can be found via the AIRC’s Use Case page. [...] On July 26, 2024, NIST releasedNIST-AI-_600-1, Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Framework: Generative Artificial Intelligence Profile_. The profile can help organizations identify unique risks posed by generative AI and proposes actions for generative AI risk management that best aligns with their goals and priorities.\n\nTo view public comments received on the previous drafts of the AI RMF and Requests for Information, see theAI RMF Developmentpage.\n\nTranslations",

      "title": "AI RMF Development | NIST",
      "url": "https://www.nist.gov/itl/ai-risk-management-framework/ai-rmf-development",
      "content": ". The NIST AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF)is intended for voluntary use and to improve the ability to incorporate trustworthiness considerations into the design, development, use, and evaluation of AI products, services, and systems. [...] Released on January 26, 2023, the Framework was developed through a consensus-driven, open, transparent, and collaborative process that included a Request for Information, several draft versions for public comments, multipleworkshops, and other opportunities to provide input. It is intended to build on, align with, and support AI risk management efforts by others.\n\nA companion NIST AI RMF Playbookalso has been published by NIST. [...] NIST released the first complete version of the NIST AI RMF Playbook on March 30, 2023\n\nNIST released the AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF) 1.0. along with a companion NIST AI RMF Playbook,NIST AI RMF Video Explainer,an AI RMF Roadmap \"),AI RMF Crosswalks \"),and various Perspectiveson January 26, 2023.\n\nNIST issued asecond draft of the AI RMFfor written comments and at theOctober 18-19, 2022, workshop.",

      "title": "NIST Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Framework (AI RMF)",
      "url": "https://www.nist.gov/system/files/documents/2024/10/07/09-24-about-the-ai-rmf-for-distro-9-25_508-edit.pdf",
      "content": "Develop AI RMF profiles. These can be either use case profiles (e.g., hiring) or temporal profiles (e.g., describing how an organization can move from its current state to its target state in managing AI risks). Translate the AI RMF into additional languages.\nContribute additional AI RMF crosswalks. [...] NIST Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Framework (AI RMF) Development of the AI RMF About The AI RMF May 2025 Developed following the National Artificial Intelligence Initiative Act of 2020 (P .L. 116-283), NIST’s AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF) is a voluntary framework to help individuals, organizations, and society manage AI’s risks and promote trustworthy development and responsible use of AI systems. Enhancements will be added to the accompanying Playbook to make the AI RMF more [...] Actions You Can Take The framework provides implementation flexibility to organizations of all sizes and in all sectors and throughout society. Released in January 2023, the AI RMF is intended to build on, align with, and support AI risk management efforts by others.\n• A NIST AI RMF Playbook suggests ways to navigate and use the AI RMF to incorporate trustworthiness considerations in the design, development, deployment, and use of AI systems.",

      "title": "Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Framework (AI RMF 1",
      "url": "https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/ai/nist.ai.100-1.pdf?utm.com",
      "content": "Page 7 NIST AI 100-1 AI RMF 1.0 When applying the AI RMF, risks which the organization determines to be highest for the AI systems within a given context of use call for the most urgent prioritization and most thorough risk management process. In cases where an AI system presents unacceptable negative risk levels – such as where significant negative impacts are imminent, severe harms are actually occurring, or catastrophic risks are present – development and deployment should cease in a safe [...] As directed by the National Artificial Intelligence Initiative Act of 2020 (P.L. 116-283), the goal of the AI RMF is to offer a resource to the organizations designing, developing, deploying, or using AI systems to help manage the many risks of AI and promote trustwor-thy and responsible development and use of AI systems. The Framework is intended to be voluntary, rights-preserving, non-sector-specific, and use-case agnostic, providing flexibil-ity to organizations of all sizes and in all [...] management may depend on existing guidelines for specific applications and use case settings. Where established guidelines do not exist, organizations should define reasonable risk tolerance. Once tolerance is defined, this AI RMF can be used to manage risks and to document risk management processes.",

      "title": "NIST AI RMF Playbook | NIST",
      "url": "https://www.nist.gov/itl/ai-risk-management-framework/nist-ai-rmf-playbook",
      "content": "In collaboration with the private and public sectors, NIST has created a companion AI RMF playbookfor voluntary use – which suggests ways to navigate and use the AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF) to incorporate trustworthiness considerations in the design, development, deployment, and use of AI systems. [...] The AI RMF and the Playbook are intended for voluntary use. Organizations may utilize this information by borrowing as many – or as few – suggestions as apply to their industry use case or interests.\n\nPlaybook content will evolve to enable community review and feedback about its informativeness, accuracy and specificity. The first complete version announced on March 30, 2023, includes options for filtering or tailoring information to user preferences and requirements. [...] The Playbook is based on AI RMF 1.0 (released on January 26, 2023). It includes suggested actions, references, and related guidance to achieve the outcomes for the four functions in the AI RMF: Govern, Map, Measure, and Manage. Playbook suggestions are developed based on best practices and research insights.",

      "title": "Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Framework (AI RMF 1.0) AI RMF Core - AIRC Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Framework (AI RMF 1 AI RMF Development | NIST",
      "url": "https://www.nist.gov/publications/artificial-intelligence-risk-management-framework-ai-rmf-10",
      "content": "As directed by the National Artificial Intelligence Initiative Act of 2020 (P.L. 116-283), the goal of the AI RMF is to offer a resource to the organizations designing, developing, deploying, or using AI systems to help manage the many risks of AI and promote trustworthy and responsible development and use of AI systems. The Framework is intended to be voluntary, rights-preserving, non-sector specific, and use-case agnostic, providing flexibility to organizations of all sizes and in all [...] sectors and throughout society to implement the approaches in the Framework. The AI RMF is intended to be practical, to adapt to the AI landscape as AI technologies continue to develop, and to be operationalized by organizations in varying degrees and capacities so society can benefit from AI while also being protected from its potential harms.       "content": "An online companion resource to the AI RMF, the NIST AI RMF Playbook, is available to help organizations navigate\nthe AI RMF and achieve its outcomes through suggested tactical actions they can apply within their own contexts.\nLike the AI RMF, the Playbook is voluntary and organizations can utilize the suggestions according to their needs\nand interests. Playbook users can create tailored guidance selected from suggested material for their own use and [...] govern, most users of the AI RMF would start with the\nmap\nfunction and continue to\nmeasure\nor\nmanage. However users integrate the functions, the process should be iterative, with cross-referencing between\nfunctions as necessary. Similarly, there are categories and subcategories with elements that apply to multiple\nfunctions, or that logically should take place before certain subcategory decisions. [...] | Map 1: Context is established and understood. | Map 1.1: Intended purposes, potentially beneficial uses, context-specific laws, norms and expectations, and prospective settings in which the AI system will be deployed are understood and documented. Considerations include: the specific set or types of users along with their expectations; potential positive and negative impacts of system uses to individuals, communities, organizations, society, and the planet; assumptions and related limitations",

[...] Despite their recognition of potential risks, employees’ perception of GenAI is notably more positive than negative (see chart below).   "query": "site:tcs.com Workday gen AI",

    "workday.com",

    "community.workday.com",

Both feel about 40% of the time they spend on administrative activities is being spent inefficiently—and both believe GenAI could help free up that time. [...] Employees recognise that GenAI, like any other technology, has both strengths and weaknesses. Among their concerns are that GenAI will increase bias against them at work, and that GenAI may produce misinformation that they won’t be able to recognise. These perceptions are more widespread among GenAI’s most frequent users. This speaks to the importance of having a supportive environment with clear governance, guidelines and training.       "title": "Responsible AI Takes Two: Developers and Deployers ...",
      "content": "As responsible AI system providers, we at Workday understand and respect our responsibility to develop trustworthy AI systems. We are also mindful that, as developers, our role occupies a specific space in the larger AI value chain. Only when all parties in that value chain commit to working together can we ensure that these technologies are used to amplify human potential and positively impact society. [...] Provide transparency to customers. Workday provides our customers with AI fact sheets for each AI tool that we offer. Only about one in five senior executives and 17% of managers say they’re using GenAI daily—a clear call to action for leaders to upskill and use GenAI as much as employees do, not just for their own work, but so that they can coach workers on ways to use it in theirs.\n\n### 4. More than 80% of workers who use GenAI daily expect it to make their time at work more efficient in the next 12 months (see chart below). [...] Despite their recognition of potential risks, employees’ perception of GenAI is notably more positive than negative (see chart below). More than 70% of employees in our survey who have used GenAI agree that the tools will create opportunities to learn new skills at work, be more creative at work and improve the quality of their work. And half of all adopters expect GenAI to lead to higher salaries—an expectation that’s even higher among those who use GenAI daily. [...] In addition, senior leaders can lead by example.       "title": "Workday Announces New AI Agents to Transform HR and Finance ...",
      "url": "https://newsroom.workday.com/2024-09-17-Workday-Announces-New-AI-Agents-to-Transform-HR-and-Finance-Processes",
      "content": "LAS VEGAS, Sept. 17, 2024 /PRNewswire/ -- Workday, Inc. (NASDAQ: WDAY), a leading provider of solutions to help organizations manage their people and money, today unveiled four new AI agents to dramatically simplify work across HR and finance. Recruiting, Expenses, Succession, and Workday Optimize Agents will anticipate and streamline common business workflows to drive productivity and free users up to do more strategic, meaningful work. [...] \"The potential for AI to revolutionize the way we work is undeniable, but for many companies, the path to significant impact has been elusive,\" said David Somers, chief product officer, Workday. \"Workday Illuminate and our new AI agents are here to change that.       "title": "How Many Identities Does One Person Need? Just ...",
      "content": "Which is why leaders at a 21st-century multinational aerospace and defense conglomerate recently found themselves pondering the state of some of their technology. They were concerned, specifically, about their identity governance and administration (IGA) system—the back-office stuff that makes sure the right people have the right access to the right things (like payroll, HR, IT, and other resources). [...] From a user perspective, the company today enjoys a single, scalable, modern IGA system that works the same for every employee regardless of position or country in which they work, with standardized processes, governance, and controls on the back end to match. Gone are manual updates, replaced by automated transactions for things like changes in HR information or application access, with up to 4 million of these transactions logged per month. New employees—more than 40,000 of them added through [...] In other words, the company was experiencing its own version of gauge breaks: no consistent, standardized way to manage employee data from point A (when they were hired) to point B (when they left), or even for points in between. So it was wasting time and effort, increasing costs and compliance risk, and decreasing operational efficiency.",
